Advanced Composition

Posted on 2020-11-13 Edited on 2020-11-15

Once we have designed some basic differentially private algorithms, it is a natural idea to combine them and analysis the privacy loss. We begin with an illustrative example that sets up the mathematical model step by step.

Image yourself in front of the door of a safe vault protected by a password lock. To open the door, you need the correct password PPP. If tried with the wrong password, the lock would destroy itself automatically.

Luckily, you know two candidate passwords P1P_1P1​ and P2P_2P2​, with one of them being the correct one. Further, you notice that the designer of the lock left a collection of boxes near the door, which contain information on how they decide the correct passwords. Obtaining complete information of anyone of them gives you the correct password.

But the boxes are also protected and you don’t have legally access to them. However, you can hack into the boxes. Hacking into the box won’t give you all its information, but a random message. In particular, each box BBB is associated with a set RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​, which is a finite collection of messages (in English). When BBB is hacked, it returns a message YBY_BYB​ generated randomly from RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​, whose distribution depends on the correct password PPP.

Let DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ be the distribution of YBY_BYB​ if the correct password is P1P_1P1​, and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ be the one if the correct password is P2P_2P2​. If there is a huge difference between DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​, then you might be able to guess the correct password.

E.g., suppose RB=\mathcal{R}_B =RB​= { “Dog bites.”, “Cat scratches.” } and the distributions are given as

DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​
“Dog bites.” 0.99 0.01
“Cat scratches.” 0.01 0.99

Hence, when you get YB=Y_B=YB​= “Dog bites.”, you prefer P1P_1P1​ over P2P_2P2​ and vice versa.

Anticipating such potential information leakage, the designer of the lock equips the boxes with a defense mechanism, called (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0)-mechanism. It guarantees the distributions DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ are similar so that it is hard for you to infer the correct password from the message. In particular, ∀S⊂RB\forall S \subset \mathcal{R}_B∀S⊂RB​, if SSS is measurable, it holds that

Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P1]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P2]Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P2]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P1]\Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_1 ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_2 ] \\ \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_2 ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_1 ] \\ Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P1​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P2​]Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P2​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P1​]

When these inequalities are satisfied, we say that DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close. The inequalities require DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ to have the same support on RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​. Therefore, throughout our discussion below, we assume that both DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ assign positive probability to each element in RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​. Otherwise, we can just replace RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​ with the support of DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ (which is also the support of DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​).

Now, hacking one box is unlikely to help you to guess the correct password. You want to hack more boxes, with the hope that the information combined will assist you. Due to resource limit, you can’t hack all boxes but only a finite number of them. You choose the first box randomly. Then you choose every new box based on the information obtained from the hacked boxes. The figure below shows an example of hacking five boxes.

Suppose that your resource enables you to hack nnn boxes and let Y⃗n=(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)\vec Y_n = (Y_1, Y_2, ..., Y_n)Yn​=(Y1​,Y2​,...,Yn​) be the output messages you obtained. Similar to the situation of hacking one box, if the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​, conditioned on P=P1P = P_1P=P1​, is utterly distant from that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​, then there could be some cases when you can confidently infer the true password. Conversely, to prevent severe information leakage, the designer needs to ensure there isn’t such case, i.e., the two distributions should be similar.

What makes things even more complicated is that, the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ depends not only on the output distributions of the boxes, but also on your strategy of choosing the boxes to hack. Let’s use symbol AAA to denote your strategy. Whatever AAA is, the designer need to guarantee that the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ conditioned P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ should be similar to that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​.

Surprisingly, this is in some sense achievable, as long as for each box, its output distribution conditioned on P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ is (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close to that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​.

Let R\mathcal{R}R be the set of possible possible messages of all boxes.

Theorem. ∀A\forall A∀A, ∀S⊂Rn\forall S \subset \mathcal{R}^n∀S⊂Rn, it holds that ∀δ′∈(0,1)\forall \delta' \in (0, 1)∀δ′∈(0,1),

Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′ \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] \le e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \\ \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] \le e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′

where ϵ′=kϵ(eϵ−1)+ϵ2nlog⁡1δ′\epsilon' = k\epsilon(e^\epsilon - 1) + \epsilon \sqrt{2 n \log \frac{1}{\delta'} }ϵ′=kϵ(eϵ−1)+ϵ2nlogδ′1​​.

If we view ϵ\epsilonϵ as the privacy loss of a single box, then the theorem states that the privacy loss grows to O(nϵ)O(\sqrt {n} \epsilon )O(n​ϵ) is nnn boxes are hacked.

To prove the theorem, we need a rigorous model for the problem.

Definitions.

  1. I\mathcal{I}I: the index set.

  2. {Bα:α∈I}\{ B_\alpha : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Bα​:α∈I}: the collection of boxes.

  3. {Rα:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{R}_{\alpha} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Rα​:α∈I}: the ranges of the outputs of the boxes.

  4. R≐∪α∈IRα\mathcal{R} \doteq \cup_{\alpha \in \mathcal{I} } R_\alphaR≐∪α∈I​Rα​: the range of any possible output by any box.

  5. {Dα,P1:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Dα,P1​​:α∈I} ({Dα,P2:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Dα,P2​​:α∈I}): the set of output distribution when the correct password is P1P_1P1​ (P2P_2P2​). Without loss of generality, we assume that for a fixed α∈I\alpha \in \mathcal{I}α∈I, the distribution Dα,P1\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1}Dα,P1​​ (Dα,P2\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2}Dα,P2​​) assigns positive probability to each element in Rα\mathcal{R}_\alphaRα​. Moreover, Dα,P1\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1}Dα,P1​​ and Dα,P2\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2}Dα,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close.

  6. nnn: the number of boxes you can hack.

  7. i⃗k≐(i1,i2,...,ik)\vec i_k \doteq (i_1, i_2, ..., i_k)ik​≐(i1​,i2​,...,ik​): the index sequence of boxes you have chosen to hack up to time kkk, where k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n]. When k=0k = 0k=0, i⃗0\vec i_0i0​ corresponds to a empty sequence.

  8. Y⃗k=(Y1,Y2,...,Yk):\vec Y_k = (Y_1, Y_2, ..., Y_k):Yk​=(Y1​,Y2​,...,Yk​): the random variables that represent messages outputted by the chosen boxes up to time k∈[1,n]k \in [1, n]k∈[1,n], where Yt∈Rit⊂RY_t \in \mathcal{R}_{i_t} \subset \mathcal{R}Yt​∈Rit​​⊂R for t∈[1,k]t \in [1, k]t∈[1,k]. Therefore, Y⃗k\vec Y_kYk​ can be view as random vector in Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk.

  9. x⃗k=(x1,x2,...,xk)∈Rk:\vec x_k = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_k) \in \mathcal{R}^k:xk​=(x1​,x2​,...,xk​)∈Rk: a point in Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk, where k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n]. When k=0k = 0k=0, we define x⃗0=∅\vec x_0 = \emptysetx0​=∅.

  10. h⃗k=<i⃗k,x⃗k>=<(i1,i2,i3,...,ik),(x1,x2,...,xk)>:\vec h_k = \left< \vec i_k, \vec x_k \right> = \left< (i_1, i_2, i_3, ..., i_k), (x_1, x_2, ..., x_k) \right>:hk​=⟨ik​,xk​⟩=⟨(i1​,i2​,i3​,...,ik​),(x1​,x2​,...,xk​)⟩: the history up to k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n], which consists of the chosen indexes and observations up to time kkk. We use h⃗0\vec h_0h0​ to denote the empty history.

  11. A:A:A: your strategy (policy) for choosing boxes. It works as follows: for any fixed history h⃗k=<i⃗k,x⃗k>\vec h_k = \left< \vec i_k, \vec x_k \right>hk​=⟨ik​,xk​⟩, A is associated with a fixed distribution DA,h⃗k\mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_k}DA,hk​​ over I∖i⃗k\mathcal{I} \setminus \vec i_kI∖ik​, the set of indexes of the unchosen boxes. When inputted with h⃗k\vec h_khk​, AAA returns a random variable A(h⃗k)A(\vec h_k)A(hk​) that follows the distribution DA,h⃗k\mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_k}DA,hk​​.

We will show that, no matter what strategy you use, it is unlikely that you distinguish via the output Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ whether the correct password is P1P_1P1​ or P2P_2P2​. This is because whether P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ or not, the output distributions of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ are similar.

Proof of the theorem. We will just prove the first inequality, and the second one follows from symmetry. We consider a bad set in Rn\mathcal{R}^nRn:

W≐{x⃗n∈Rn:Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]≥eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]}\mathcal{W} \doteq \{ \vec x_n \in \mathcal{R}^n : \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] \ge e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] \} W≐{xn​∈Rn:Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]≥eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]}

and will use the following lemma.

Lemma. Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈W ∣ P=P1,A]≤δ′\Pr[ \vec Y_n \in \mathcal{W}\ | \ P = P_1, A] \le \delta'Pr[Yn​∈W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤δ′.

Hence,

Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]=Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩W ∣ P=P1,A]≤Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈W ∣ P=P1,A]≤Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′=∑x⃗n∈S∩WˉPr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′<∑x⃗n∈S∩Wˉeϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′=eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] &= \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \mathcal{W} \ | \ P = P_1, A] \\ &\le \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in \mathcal{W} \ | \ P = P_1, A] \\ &\le \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' \\ &= \sum_{ \vec x_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } } \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' \\ &< \sum_{ \vec x_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } } e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \\ &= e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]​=Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+Pr[Yn​∈S∩W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+Pr[Yn​∈W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′=xn​∈S∩Wˉ∑​Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′<xn​∈S∩Wˉ∑​eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′=eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′​

The first inequality follows from monotonicity of probability, the second one from the lemma, and the final one from the definition of W\mathcal{W}W.

Proof of the lemma. To prove the lemma, we need only to consider those point x⃗n\vec x_nxn​ with

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]>0.\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] > 0. Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]>0.

Otherwise, x⃗n\vec x_nxn​ contributes to 0 probability to the set W\mathcal{W}W (whether it belongs to W\mathcal{W}W or not).

Now, we expand the probability Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A]Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]. To obtain the kkk-th output, there are two steps

  1. AAA generates a index iki_kik​ of a box based on the known history h⃗k−1\vec h_{k - 1}hk−1​.
  2. The box BikB_{i_k}Bik​​ is hacked, and output a random message xkx_kxk​ sampled from its distribution Dik,P1D_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​.

Let H⃗k\vec H_kHk​ be a random variable that represents the history up to kkk. By chain rule, we have

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]=∏k=1nPr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]  ⋅∏k=1nPr⁡A(h⃗k−1)∼DA,h⃗k−1[A(h⃗k−1)=ik∣H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] &= \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] \\ &\ \ \cdot \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) \sim \mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_{k - 1} } } [ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k \mid \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]​=k=1∏n​Yk​∼Dik​,P1​​Pr​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]  ⋅k=1∏n​A(hk−1​)∼DA,hk−1​​Pr​[A(hk−1​)=ik​∣Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​

By Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]>0\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] > 0Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]>0, each term in the expansion are positive. Similarly,

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]=∏k=1nPr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]  ⋅∏k=1nPr⁡A(h⃗k−1)∼DA,h⃗k−1[A(h⃗k−1)=ik∣H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] &= \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] \\ &\ \ \cdot \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) \sim \mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_{k - 1} } } [ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k \mid \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]​=k=1∏n​Yk​∼Dik​,P2​​Pr​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]  ⋅k=1∏n​A(hk−1​)∼DA,hk−1​​Pr​[A(hk−1​)=ik​∣Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]​

As both Dik,P1\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​ and Dik,P2\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2}Dik​,P2​​ assign positive probability to each point in Rik\mathcal{R}_{i_k}Rik​​, we know Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]>0\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] > 0Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]>0.

We are ready to consider the ratio:

ln⁡Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]=∑k=1nln⁡Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A].\begin{aligned} \ln \frac{ \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] }{ \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] } = \sum_{k = 1}^n \ln \frac{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] }{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] }. \end{aligned} lnPr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]​=k=1∑n​lnPrYk​∼Dik​,P2​​​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]PrYk​∼Dik​,P1​​​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​.​

If we replace xkx_kxk​ by a random variable Xk∼Dik,P1X_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Xk​∼Dik​,P1​​, then

Ck≐ln⁡Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=Xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=Xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]C_k \doteq \ln \frac{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = X_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] }{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = X_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] } Ck​≐lnPrYk​∼Dik​,P2​​​[Yk​=Xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]PrYk​∼Dik​,P1​​​[Yk​=Xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​

is a random variable. As Dik,P1\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​ and Dik,P2\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2}Dik​,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close, we have

Ck≤ϵ.C_k \le \epsilon. Ck​≤ϵ.

Further, we have

Fact 1. For any α∈I\alpha \in \mathcal{I}α∈I, it holds that

EX∼Dα,P1[ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=X]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=X]]=∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]≤∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]+∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P2[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]=∑x∈Rα[Pr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]−Pr⁡X∼Dα,P2[X=x]]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} } \left[ \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = X] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = X] } \right] &= \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &\le \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &+ \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &= \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \left[ \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] - \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \right] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &\le (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilon \end{aligned} EX∼Dα,P1​​​⎣⎢⎡​lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=X]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=X]​⎦⎥⎤​​=x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​≤x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​+x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]​=x∈Rα​∑​[X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]−X∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[X=x]]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​≤(eϵ−1)ϵ​

Therefore, E[Ck]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ\mathbb{E} [C_k] \le (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilonE[Ck​]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ.

Fact 2. (Azuma Inequality). Let C1,....,CnC_1, ...., C_nC1​,....,Cn​ be random variables such that ∀k∈[n]\forall k \in [n]∀k∈[n], Pr⁡[∣Ck∣≤ϵ]=1\Pr[ |C_k| \le \epsilon ] = 1Pr[∣Ck​∣≤ϵ]=1, and for every (c1,...,ck−1)∈Supp(C1,...,Ck−1)(c_1, ..., c_{k -1} ) \in \text{Supp} (C_1, ..., C_{k - 1} )(c1​,...,ck−1​)∈Supp(C1​,...,Ck−1​), we have

E[Ci∣C1=c1,...,Ck−1=ck−1]≤β,\mathbb{E}[ C_i \mid C_1 = c_1, ..., C_{k -1} = c_{k - 1} ] \le \beta, E[Ci​∣C1​=c1​,...,Ck−1​=ck−1​]≤β,

Then for every z>0z > 0z>0, we have

Pr⁡[∑k=1nCi−nβ>z]≤exp⁡(−z22nϵ2)\Pr[ \sum_{k = 1}^n C_i - n \beta > z] \le \exp(- \frac{z^2}{ 2 n\epsilon^2 } ) Pr[k=1∑n​Ci​−nβ>z]≤exp(−2nϵ2z2​)

Finally, applying Azuma Inequality with z=2nlog⁡1δ′z = \sqrt{ 2n \log \frac{1}{\delta'} }z=2nlogδ′1​​ and β=(eϵ−1)ϵ\beta = (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilonβ=(eϵ−1)ϵ, we get the desired result.

■\blacksquare■

Reference.

[1] C. Dwork and A. Roth, “The Algorithmic Foundations of Differential Privacy,” Foundations and Trends® in Theoretical Computer Science, vol. 9, no. 3–4, pp. 211–407, 2013

PAC Learning Basic

Posted on 2020-11-12 Edited on 2021-11-09

We discuss a toy model of probably approximately correct (PAC) learning [1].
The setting focuses on a ddd-dimension Boolean hypercube {0,1}d\{0, 1\}^d{0,1}d and a set of functions H={h:{0,1}d→{0,1}}\mathcal{H} = \{ h : \{0, 1\}^d \rightarrow \{0, 1 \} \}H={h:{0,1}d→{0,1}}.
A function h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H is called a hypothesis or a concept, which assigns each vertex in the hypercube a label 0 or 1.

The goal of PAC learning is to learn an unknown hypothesis, denoted as h∗∈Hh^* \in \mathcal{H}h∗∈H, from a dataset, which consists of nnn points X1,X2,…,Xn∈{0,1}nX_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n \in \{0, 1\}^nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​∈{0,1}n sampled independently from an unknown distribution DDD (over the hypercube), as well as their labels Y1=h∗(X1),Y2=h∗(X2),…,Yn=h∗(Xn)Y_1 = h^*(X_1), Y_2 = h^*(X_2), \ldots, Y_n = h^*(X_n)Y1​=h∗(X1​),Y2​=h∗(X2​),…,Yn​=h∗(Xn​).

We can state the algorithm for PAC learning in just one sentence.

Output any hypothesis h′∈Hh' \in \mathcal{H}h′∈H that is consistent with the sampled dataset, i.e.,

h′(Xi)=Yi,∀i∈[n] h'(X_i) = Y_i, \qquad \forall i \in [n] h′(Xi​)=Yi​,∀i∈[n]

Such an hypothesis always exists, as h∗h^*h∗ satisfies this constraint.
We have the classic PAC learning theorem.

Theorem. Let X∈{0,1}nX \in \{0, 1\}^nX∈{0,1}n be a random point sampled from the unknown distribution, then for a given δ∈(0,1)\delta \in (0, 1)δ∈(0,1),

Pr⁡[h′(X)≠h∗(X)]≥log⁡∣H∣+log⁡1δ2n \Pr[ h'(X) \neq h^*(X)] \ge \sqrt{ \log |\mathcal{H}| + \log \frac{ 1 }{ \delta } \over 2n} Pr[h′(X)=h∗(X)]≥2nlog∣H∣+logδ1​​​

with probability at most δ\deltaδ.

The PAC learning theorem states that the probability that h′h'h′ mislabels a point is bounded by log⁡∣H∣+log⁡(1/δ)2n\sqrt{ \log |\mathcal{H}| + \log ( 1 / \delta ) \over 2n}2nlog∣H∣+log(1/δ)​​.

Proof. Consider some fixed h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H. For convenience, we rewrite

Pr⁡[h(X)≠h∗(X)]=μh. \Pr[ h(X) \neq h^*(X)] = \mu_h. Pr[h(X)=h∗(X)]=μh​.

Denote ZiZ_iZi​ the indicator variable of whether hhh mislabels XiX_iXi​, i.e.,

Zi={0, if h(Xi)=Yi1, if h(Xi)≠Yi Z_i = \begin{cases} 0, \qquad \text{ if } h(X_i) = Y_i \\ 1, \qquad \text{ if } h(X_i) \neq Y_i \end{cases} Zi​={0, if h(Xi​)=Yi​1, if h(Xi​)=Yi​​

By definition, E[Zi]\mathbb{E}[Z_i]E[Zi​] is an unbiased estimator of μh\mu_hμh​. Further, denote μ^h\hat \mu_hμ^​h​ the empirical mean of ZiZ_iZi​’s

μ^h≐1n∑i∈[n]Zi. \hat \mu_h \doteq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i \in [n] } Z_i. μ^​h​≐n1​i∈[n]∑​Zi​.

Note that for the outputted h′h'h′, μ^h′=0\hat \mu_{h'} = 0μ^​h′​=0.

By Hoeffding inequality, for any δ′>0\delta' > 0δ′>0,

Pr⁡[μ^h≤μh−log⁡(1/δ′)2n]≤δ′. \Pr \left[ \hat \mu_h \le \mu_h - \sqrt{ \frac{ \log ( 1 / \delta') }{2n} } \right] \le \delta'. Pr[μ^​h​≤μh​−2nlog(1/δ′)​​]≤δ′.

By union bound, the probability that

∃h∈H,μ^h≥μh−log⁡(1/δ′)2n \exists h \in \mathcal{H}, \hat \mu_h \ge \mu_h - \sqrt{ \frac{ \log ( 1 / \delta') }{2n} } ∃h∈H,μ^​h​≥μh​−2nlog(1/δ′)​​

is bounded by ∣H∣δ′| \mathcal{H} | \delta'∣H∣δ′. By setting δ′=δ∣H∣\delta' = \frac{\delta}{ | \mathcal{H} | }δ′=∣H∣δ​, it is guaranteed that with probability at most δ\deltaδ,

0=μ^h′≤μh′−log⁡∣H∣+log⁡(1/δ)2n. 0 = \hat \mu_{h' } \le \mu_{h'} - \sqrt{ \log |\mathcal{H}| + \log ( 1 / \delta) \over 2n}. 0=μ^​h′​≤μh′​−2nlog∣H∣+log(1/δ)​​.

■\blacksquare■

The previous theorem can be improved with the ⋅\sqrt{ \cdot }⋅​ removed. The key here is that the selected h′h'h′ is error-free on the samples.

Theorem. Let X∈{0,1}nX \in \{0, 1\}^nX∈{0,1}n be a random point sampled from the unknown distribution, then for a given δ∈(0,1)\delta \in (0, 1)δ∈(0,1),

Pr⁡[h′(X)≠h∗(X)]≥log⁡∣H∣+log⁡1δn \Pr[ h'(X) \neq h^*(X)] \ge { \log |\mathcal{H}| + \log \frac{ 1 }{ \delta } \over n} Pr[h′(X)=h∗(X)]≥nlog∣H∣+logδ1​​

with probability at most δ\deltaδ.

Proof. Consider some fixed h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H. For convenience, we rewrite

Pr⁡[h(X)≠h∗(X)]=μh. \Pr[ h(X) \neq h^*(X)] = \mu_h. Pr[h(X)=h∗(X)]=μh​.

We will prove that if μh≥log⁡∣H∣+log⁡1δn\mu_h \ge { \log |\mathcal{H}| + \log \frac{ 1 }{ \delta } \over n}μh​≥nlog∣H∣+logδ1​​, then hhh’s probability of being selected is very low.

Denote ZiZ_iZi​ the indicator variable of whether hhh mislabels XiX_iXi​, i.e.,

Zi={0, if h(Xi)=Yi1, if h(Xi)≠Yi Z_i = \begin{cases} 0, \qquad \text{ if } h(X_i) = Y_i \\ 1, \qquad \text{ if } h(X_i) \neq Y_i \end{cases} Zi​={0, if h(Xi​)=Yi​1, if h(Xi​)=Yi​​

By definition, Pr⁡[Zi=1]=μh\Pr[Z_i = 1] = \mu_hPr[Zi​=1]=μh​. Therefore,

Pr⁡[Z1=0∧Z2=0∧…∧Zn=0]=(1−μh)n≤exp⁡(−μhn)=δ∣H∣ \begin{aligned} \Pr[ Z_1 = 0 \wedge Z_2 = 0 \wedge \ldots \wedge Z_n = 0] = (1 - \mu_h)^n \le \exp(- \mu_h n) = \frac{\delta}{ |\mathcal{H} | } \end{aligned} Pr[Z1​=0∧Z2​=0∧…∧Zn​=0]=(1−μh​)n≤exp(−μh​n)=∣H∣δ​​

Taking union bound over all possible hhh gives the desired result.

■\blacksquare■

Caveat. In both theorem, we see a log⁡H\log \mathcal{H}logH term in the failure probability, which is due to the use of union bound and can be roughly considered as the complexity of the hypothesis family. It is tempting to think that this could be avoid as follows.

For the outputted h′h'h′, Z1,…,ZnZ_1, \ldots, Z_nZ1​,…,Zn​ are i.i.d samples. Therefore, the probability of all of them being 000 is give by

(1−μh′)n≤exp⁡(−μh′n). (1 - \mu_{h'} )^n \le \exp( - \mu_{h'} n). (1−μh′​)n≤exp(−μh′​n).

Bounding this probability by δ\deltaδ gives μh′≤log⁡(1/δ)n\mu_{h'} \le \frac{ \log ( 1 / \delta ) } {n}μh′​≤nlog(1/δ)​.

The argument is wrong. For the outputted h′h'h′, the Z1,…,ZnZ_1, \ldots, Z_nZ1​,…,Zn​ are not i.i.d samples, as h′h'h′ is selected according to Z1,…,ZnZ_1, \ldots, Z_nZ1​,…,Zn​ and depends on them.

To make it more concrete, suppose that there is an hhh, such that μh=log⁡(1/δ)n\mu_h = \frac{ \log ( 1 / \delta ) } {n}μh​=nlog(1/δ)​. Consider the following experiment

  1. Sample nnn points independently the distribution DDD.
  2. Pick an h′h'h′ that makes no prediction error on the samples.

If we repeat the experiment NNN times for some positive integer NNN, then the fixed hhh makes no mistake in roughly (1−δ)N(1 - \delta) N(1−δ)N of the experiments and constitutes an candidate of h′h'h′. However, on the other roughly δN\delta NδN experiments, where hhh makes prediction error, it is no longer considered as the candidate of h′h'h′. The selection procedure of h′h'h′ ignores bad event of hhh automatically.

We could also investigate the following example. Let h∗=h0h^* = h_0h∗=h0​. There are also other two hypothesis h1h_1h1​ and h2h_2h2​. Let SSS be the sample space. It holds that

∣h1(x)−h∗(x)∣={2ϵ,∀x∈S∖Sh10,  ∀x∈Sh1 |h_1(x) - h^*(x) | = \begin{cases} 2 \epsilon, \forall x \in S \setminus S_{h_1} \\ 0,\ \ \forall x \in S_{h_1} \end{cases} ∣h1​(x)−h∗(x)∣={2ϵ,∀x∈S∖Sh1​​0,  ∀x∈Sh1​​​

∣h2(x)−h∗(x)∣={2ϵ,∀x∈S∖Sh20,  ∀x∈Sh2 |h_2(x) - h^*(x) | = \begin{cases} 2 \epsilon, \forall x \in S \setminus S_{h_2} \\ 0,\ \ \forall x \in S_{h_2} \end{cases} ∣h2​(x)−h∗(x)∣={2ϵ,∀x∈S∖Sh2​​0,  ∀x∈Sh2​​​

Moreover, Pr⁡[Sh1]=Pr⁡[Sh2]=δ\Pr[S_{h_1}] = \Pr[S_{h_2} ] = \deltaPr[Sh1​​]=Pr[Sh2​​]=δ. How, if we get a sample in Sh1S_{h_1}Sh1​​, then we can output h′h'h′ as h0h_0h0​ or h1h_1h1​, since both of them make no error when x∈Sh1x \in S_{h_1}x∈Sh1​​. Similarly, if x∈Sh2x \in S_{h_2}x∈Sh2​​, we can output either h0h_0h0​ or h2h_2h2​. We call Sh1S_{h_1}Sh1​​ and Sh2S_{h_2}Sh2​​ the bad areas. When xxx is in the bad area of any hypothesis, we can’t distinguish this hypothesis from the true hypothesis. That is why we need to use union bound to bound the total probabilities of these bad areas.

Reference

[1] Leslie G. Valiant. A theory of the learnable. Communications of the ACM, 27(11):1134-1142, 1984. 6

Gaussian Distribution

Posted on 2020-11-06 Edited on 2022-12-20

Gaussian Distribution

We show how Gaussian distribution (a.k.a. normal distribution) is constructed and list some of its basic properties.

Suppose we would like to have a distribution in R\mathbb{R}R, such that

  1. It is centered at the origin.
  2. Its density function decreases exponentially with respect to the square distance to the origin.

Remark: if we replace 2 with “a density function decreases exponentially with the distance to the origin”, we obtain Laplace distribution.

The density function p(x)p(x)p(x) should be inversely and exponentially proportional to x2x^2x2:

p(x)∝exp⁡(−x2) p(x) \propto \exp(-x^2 ) p(x)∝exp(−x2)

Denote MMM the value of

M≐∫−∞∞exp⁡(−x2) dx. M \doteq \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp(-x^2) \ dx. M≐∫−∞∞​exp(−x2) dx.

It is easy to check that MMM is finite.
Then the close form of p(x)p(x)p(x) is

p(x)=1Mexp⁡(−x2). p(x) = \frac{1}{M} \exp(- x^2). p(x)=M1​exp(−x2).

It is easy to verity that p(x)p(x)p(x) is a valid density function: ∫−∞∞p(x) dx=1\int_{-\infty}^\infty p(x) \ dx = 1∫−∞∞​p(x) dx=1.

Closed Form

Theorem.
p(x)=1πexp⁡(−x2) p(x) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt \pi} \exp( - x^2 ) p(x)=π​1​exp(−x2)
is a density function.

In general, it is not hard to construct a distribution. Let h(x)h(x)h(x) be any integrable function on a domain D\mathcal{D}D such that

M=∫Dh(x) dx<∞ M = \int_\mathcal{D} h(x) \ dx < \infty M=∫D​h(x) dx<∞

Then we can view h(x)h(x)h(x) as almost an density function of some distribution.
The only obstacle is that MMM might not be 111.
However this is easy to fix.
We scale the value of h(x)h(x)h(x) by a constant factor at each point by setting

p(x)=1Mh(x). p(x) = \frac{1}{M} h(x). p(x)=M1​h(x).

In this case, we don’t even need to know the exact value of MMM.
We only need to guarantee that

The value of MMM exists and is finite.

Then we can safely rely on MMM as a normalized. For example, we know that

∫0∞x0.2e−x dx≤∫01e−x dx+∫1∞xe−x dx<∞. \int_0^\infty x^{0.2} e^{-x} \ dx \le \int_0^1 e^{-x} \ dx + \int_1^\infty x e^{-x} \ dx < \infty. ∫0∞​x0.2e−x dx≤∫01​e−x dx+∫1∞​xe−x dx<∞.

We can construct a density function as discussed above.
It turns out that this is a special case of Gamma distribution.

For Gaussian distribution, we are lucky as the closed form of MMM does exists, due to the following “squaring trick”:

M2=(∫−∞∞exp⁡(−x2) dx)2=∫−∞∞exp⁡(−x2) dx ⋅∫−∞∞exp⁡(−y2) dy=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞exp⁡(−(x+y)2) dxdy.\begin{aligned} M^2 &= \Big( \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp( -x^2 ) \ dx \Big)^2 \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp( -x^2 ) \ dx \ \cdot \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp( -y^2 ) \ dy \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp( -(x + y) ^2 ) \ dx dy. \end{aligned} M2​=(∫−∞∞​exp(−x2) dx)2=∫−∞∞​exp(−x2) dx ⋅∫−∞∞​exp(−y2) dy=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​exp(−(x+y)2) dxdy.​

Denote r≐x2+y2r \doteq \sqrt{ x^2 + y^2}r≐x2+y2​ the distance of (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) to (0,0)(0, 0)(0,0).
We are integrating the function exp⁡(−r2)\exp( - r^2)exp(−r2) over the plane R2\mathbb{R}^2R2.
It is natural to switch to polar coordinate system (r,θ)(r, \theta)(r,θ), where θ\thetaθ is the angle of a point.
Here is an informal but intuitive explanation.
As the picture below demonstrates, if rrr increases by drdrdr and θ\thetaθ increases by dθd\thetadθ, the new area spanned by drdrdr and dθd \thetadθ is roughly rdrdθr dr d \thetardrdθ.
We can also calculate this algebraically

12[(r+dr)2−r2]dθ=rdrdθ+12(dr)2dθ≈rdrdθ.\frac{1}{2} [(r + dr)^2 - r^2] d\theta = r dr d \theta + \frac{1}{2} (dr)^2 d \theta \approx r dr d \theta. 21​[(r+dr)2−r2]dθ=rdrdθ+21​(dr)2dθ≈rdrdθ.

Finally,

M2=∫02π∫0∞exp⁡(−r2)rdrdθ=∫02π12∫0∞exp⁡(−r2)dr2dθ=∫02π12dθ=π.\begin{aligned} M^2 &= \int_{0}^{ 2 \pi} \int_{0}^\infty \exp( -r^2 ) r d r d \theta \\ &= \int_{0}^{ 2 \pi} \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^\infty \exp( -r^2 ) d r^2 d \theta \\ &= \int_{0}^{ 2 \pi} \frac{1}{2} d \theta \\ &= \pi. \end{aligned} M2​=∫02π​∫0∞​exp(−r2)rdrdθ=∫02π​21​∫0∞​exp(−r2)dr2dθ=∫02π​21​dθ=π.​

Basic Properties

Expectation

As the distribution is symmetric to 000, it has expectation 0.

Variance

As its expectation is 0, the variance is given by

∫−∞∞x2πexp⁡(−x2) dx=−12π∫−∞∞x dexp⁡(−x2)=12π∫−∞∞exp⁡(−x2)dx=12ππ=12\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{ x^2 }{ \sqrt \pi } \exp( -x^2 ) \ dx &= -\frac{1}{2 \sqrt \pi } \int_{-\infty}^\infty x \ d \exp( -x^2 ) \\ &= \frac{1}{2 \sqrt \pi } \int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp( -x^2 ) d x\\ &= \frac{1}{2 \sqrt \pi } \sqrt \pi \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \end{aligned} ∫−∞∞​π​x2​exp(−x2) dx​=−2π​1​∫−∞∞​x dexp(−x2)=2π​1​∫−∞∞​exp(−x2)dx=2π​1​π​=21​​

General Gaussian Distribution

We have proved that if XXX is a random variable with density function p(x)=1πexp⁡(−x2)p(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt \pi} \exp( -x^2)p(x)=π​1​exp(−x2), then

Var[X]=12. \mathbb{Var}[X] = \frac{1}{2}. Var[X]=21​.

Define another random variable Y≐2XY \doteq \sqrt{2} XY≐2​X, whose variance is

Var[X]=2Var[X]=1. \mathbb{Var}[X] = 2 \mathbb{Var}[X] = 1. Var[X]=2Var[X]=1.

To obtain its density function of YYY, we first scale the function p(x)p(x)p(x) horizontally by a factor of 2\sqrt 22​ to get

1πexp⁡(−x22). \frac{1}{ \sqrt{ \pi } } \exp \Big( -\frac{x^2}{2} \Big). π​1​exp(−2x2​).

Now the area under the curve f(x)=1πexp⁡(−x2/2)f(x) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt{ \pi } } \exp \big( - x^2 / {2} \big)f(x)=π​1​exp(−x2/2) is 2\sqrt 22​.
We normalize this area to 111 and obtain YYY’s density function as

p(y)=12πexp⁡(−y22) p(y) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt{2 \pi } } \exp \Big( -\frac{y^2}{2} \Big) p(y)=2π​1​exp(−2y2​)

In what follows, we use N(0,1)N(0, 1)N(0,1) to denote a Gaussian distribution with mean 0 and variance 111.
We can also scale XXX by a factor of 2σ\sqrt 2 \sigma2​σ for any σ>0\sigma > 0σ>0, to get Y=2σXY = \sqrt 2 \sigma XY=2​σX.
It have variance σ2\sigma^2σ2 and density function

p(y)=12πσ2exp⁡(−(y2σ)2)=12πσ2exp⁡(−y22σ2). p(y) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2} } \exp \Big( - \Big(\frac{y}{ \sqrt{2} \sigma } \Big)^2 \Big) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2 } } \exp \Big( -\frac{y^2}{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big). p(y)=2πσ2​1​exp(−(2​σy​)2)=2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ2y2​).

Finally, we can shift the center of 000 by any real number μ∈R\mu \in \mathbb{R}μ∈R to obtain a new density function

p(y)=1π⋅2σ2exp⁡(−(y−μ)22σ2). p(y) = \frac{1}{ \sqrt{ \pi \cdot 2 \sigma^2 } } \exp\Big( -\frac{ (y - \mu)^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big). p(y)=π⋅2σ2​1​exp(−2σ2(y−μ)2​).

The corresponding distribution is denoted as N(μ,σ2)N(\mu, \sigma^2)N(μ,σ2).

The picture below shows a few Gaussian distributions.

Advanced Properties

Sum of Normal Random Variables

If X∼N(μ1,σ12)X \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2)X∼N(μ1​,σ12​) and Y∼N(μ2,σ22)Y \sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)Y∼N(μ2​,σ22​), then for each a,b∈Ra, b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R,

aX+bY∼N(aμ1+bμ2,a2σ12+b2σ22). a X + b Y \sim N(a \mu_1 + b \mu_2 , a^2 \sigma_1^2 + b^2 \sigma_2^2). aX+bY∼N(aμ1​+bμ2​,a2σ12​+b2σ22​).

Let X′,Y′∼N(0,1)X', Y' \sim N(0, 1)X′,Y′∼N(0,1).
Then X=μ1+σ1X′X = \mu_1 + \sigma_1 X'X=μ1​+σ1​X′ and Y=μ2+σ2Y′Y = \mu_2 + \sigma_2 Y'Y=μ2​+σ2​Y′,
and

aX+bY=aμ1+bμ2+aσ1X′+bσ2Y′. a X + b Y = a \mu_1 + b \mu_2 + a \sigma_1 X' + b \sigma_2 Y'. aX+bY=aμ1​+bμ2​+aσ1​X′+bσ2​Y′.

It suffices to prove that if X′,Y′∼N(0,1)X', Y' \sim N(0, 1)X′,Y′∼N(0,1),

aσ1X′+bσ2Y′∼N(0,a2σ12+b2σ22),∀a,b∈R,∀σ1,σ2∈R≥0. a \sigma_1 X' + b \sigma_2 Y' \sim N(0, a^2 \sigma_1^2 + b^2 \sigma_2^2), \quad \forall a, b \in \mathbb{R}, \forall \sigma_1, \sigma_2 \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}. aσ1​X′+bσ2​Y′∼N(0,a2σ12​+b2σ22​),∀a,b∈R,∀σ1​,σ2​∈R≥0​.

Hence, we can assume without lose of generality that X,Y∼N(0,1)X, Y \sim N(0, 1)X,Y∼N(0,1), and prove that aX+bY∼N(0,a2+b2)a X + bY \sim N(0, a^2 + b^2)aX+bY∼N(0,a2+b2) for each a,b∈Ra, b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R.

The demonstration here follows from [1]. The key observation is that if X,Y∼N(0,1)X, Y \sim N(0, 1)X,Y∼N(0,1), the joint distribution of XXX and YYY is rotation invariant with the origin.

The figure below shows the same distribution. Observe again that the probability mass concentrates at a small region centered at origin.

Therefore, for any t∈Rt \in \mathbb{R}t∈R, the set

{(x,y)∈R2:ax+by≤t} \{ (x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 : ax + by \le t \} {(x,y)∈R2:ax+by≤t}

has the same probability measure as the one

{(x,y)∈R2:x≤ta2+b2}. \Big\{ (x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 : x \le \frac{ t}{ \sqrt{a^2 + b^2} } \Big\}. {(x,y)∈R2:x≤a2+b2​t​}.

Observe that the latter can be obtained by rotating the former with respect to the origin (see the figure below).

Now, the probability of the latter set is given by

Pr⁡[X≤ta2+b2]=Pr⁡[a2+b2X≤t] \Pr \Big[ X \le \frac{ t}{ \sqrt{a^2 + b^2} } \Big] = \Pr\Big[ \sqrt{a^2 + b^2} X \le t \Big] Pr[X≤a2+b2​t​]=Pr[a2+b2​X≤t]

It concludes that X+YX + YX+Y has the same distribution as a2+b2X∼N(0,a2+b2)\sqrt{a^2 + b^2} X \sim N(0, a^2 + b^2)a2+b2​X∼N(0,a2+b2).

Concentration Inequalities

Bound 1

If X∼N(0,σ2)X \sim N(0, \sigma^2)X∼N(0,σ2), then ∀t>0\forall t > 0∀t>0,

Pr⁡[∣X∣≥t]≤exp⁡(−t22σ2) \Pr[ |X| \ge t] \le \exp \Big( -\frac{t^2}{ 2\sigma^2} \Big) Pr[∣X∣≥t]≤exp(−2σ2t2​)

Remark: it is possible to get a tighter bound by using more advanced techniques.

Intuition: in previous figures, it seems Gaussian distributions have a shape bump around its mean.
This is kind of mis-leading, because the x-axis and y-axis are scaled.
In the figure below, we plot N(0,1)N(0, 1)N(0,1), with ratio between xxx and yyy axes being approximate 1:11:11:1.
We see only a small bump around its mean.
Although the distribution span the entire range of R\mathbb{R}R, the probability mass is centered tightly around the origin.

Proof by Moment Generating Function

We prove a weaker version by a factor of 222. For all λ∈R\lambda \in \mathbb{R}λ∈R,

E[eλX]=12πσ∫eλxe−x22σ2 dx=eλ2σ2/22πσ∫e−(x−λσ2)22σ2 dx=eλ2σ2/2. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[ e^{\lambda X} ] &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma} }\int e^{\lambda x} e^{ - \frac{x^2}{2 \sigma^2 } } \ d x \\ &= \frac{ e^{\lambda^2 \sigma^2 / 2} }{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma} }\int e^{ - \frac{ (x - \lambda \sigma^2)^2}{2 \sigma^2 } } \ d x \\ &= e^{\lambda^2 \sigma^2 / 2}. \end{aligned} E[eλX]​=2πσ​1​∫eλxe−2σ2x2​ dx=2πσ​eλ2σ2/2​∫e−2σ2(x−λσ2)2​ dx=eλ2σ2/2.​

Via Markov’s inequality, for all λ≥0\lambda \ge 0λ≥0, we have

Pr⁡[X≥t]≤E[eλX]eλt≤eλ2σ2/2−λt. \begin{aligned} \Pr[ X \ge t] &\le \frac{ \mathbb{E}[ e^{\lambda X} ] }{ e^{\lambda t} } &\le e^{\lambda^2 \sigma^2 / 2 - \lambda t}. \end{aligned} Pr[X≥t]​≤eλtE[eλX]​​≤eλ2σ2/2−λt.​

Setting λ=tσ2\lambda = \frac{t}{\sigma^2}λ=σ2t​, we get

Pr⁡[X≥t]≤e−t22σ2. \Pr[ X \ge t ] \le e^{ - \frac{t^2}{2 \sigma^2} }. Pr[X≥t]≤e−2σ2t2​.

It concludes that Pr⁡[∣X∣≥t]≤2e−t22σ2.\Pr[ |X| \ge t ] \le 2 e^{ - \frac{t^2}{2 \sigma^2} }.Pr[∣X∣≥t]≤2e−2σ2t2​.

Proof by Geometry

Let T=Pr⁡[∣X∣≥t]T = \Pr[ |X| \ge t]T=Pr[∣X∣≥t].
Then

T2=∫∣x∣≥t,∣y∣≥t12πσ2exp⁡(−x2+y22σ2). T^2 = \int_{ |x| \ge t, |y| \ge t} \frac{1}{ 2 \pi \sigma^2 } \exp \Big( - \frac{ x^2 + y^2}{2 \sigma^2} \Big). T2=∫∣x∣≥t,∣y∣≥t​2πσ21​exp(−2σ2x2+y2​).

As

{(x,y)∈R2:∣x∣≥t∧∣y∣≥t}⊂{(x,y)∈R2:x2+y2≥2t2} \{ (x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^2: |x| \ge t \wedge |y| \ge t \} \subset \{ (x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^2: x^2 + y^2 \ge 2 t^2 \} {(x,y)∈R2:∣x∣≥t∧∣y∣≥t}⊂{(x,y)∈R2:x2+y2≥2t2}

It follows that

T2≤∫2t∞∫02π12πσ2exp⁡(−r22σ2)r dθdr≤∫2t∞exp⁡(−r22σ2) dr22σ2≤∫t2σ2∞exp⁡(−z) dz=exp⁡(−t2σ2).\begin{aligned} T^2 &\le \int_{ \sqrt 2 t}^\infty \int_{0}^{2 \pi } \frac{1}{ 2 \pi \sigma^2 } \exp \Big( - \frac{ r^2 }{2 \sigma^2} \Big) r \ d\theta dr\\ &\le \int_{ \sqrt 2 t }^\infty \exp \Big( - \frac{ r^2 }{2 \sigma^2} \Big) \ d \frac{r^2}{ 2\sigma^2} \\ &\le \int_{ \frac{ t^2 }{ \sigma^2 } }^\infty \exp ( - z ) \ d z \\ &= \exp \Big( -\frac{t^2}{ \sigma^2} \Big). \end{aligned} T2​≤∫2​t∞​∫02π​2πσ21​exp(−2σ2r2​)r dθdr≤∫2​t∞​exp(−2σ2r2​) d2σ2r2​≤∫σ2t2​∞​exp(−z) dz=exp(−σ2t2​).​

Therefore,

T≤exp⁡(−t22σ2). T \le \exp \Big( - \frac{t^2}{ 2\sigma^2} \Big). T≤exp(−2σ2t2​).

Bound 2

If X∼N(0,σ2)X \sim N(0, \sigma^2)X∼N(0,σ2), then ∀t>0\forall t > 0∀t>0,

Pr⁡[X≥t]≤σ2πtexp⁡(−t22σ2). \Pr[ X \ge t] \le \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } t } \exp \Big( -\frac{t^2}{ 2\sigma^2} \Big). Pr[X≥t]≤2π​tσ​exp(−2σ2t2​).

By symmetry we also have

Pr⁡[X≤−t]≤σ2πtexp⁡(−t22σ2). \Pr[ X \le -t] \le \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } t } \exp \Big( -\frac{t^2}{ 2\sigma^2} \Big). Pr[X≤−t]≤2π​tσ​exp(−2σ2t2​).

Proof.

Pr⁡[X>t]=∫t∞12πσ2exp⁡(−x22σ2) dx≤∫t∞12πσ2xtexp⁡(−x22σ2) dx≤σ2πt∫t∞exp⁡(−x22σ2) dx22σ2=−σ2πtexp⁡(−x22σ2)∣t∞=σ2πtexp⁡(−t22σ2). \begin{aligned} \Pr[X > t] &= \int_{t}^\infty \frac{1}{ \sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2} } \exp \Big( - \frac{ x^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big) \ dx \\ &\le \int_{t}^\infty \frac{1}{ \sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2} } \frac{x}{t} \exp \Big( - \frac{ x^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big) \ dx \\ &\le \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } t } \int_{t}^\infty \exp \Big( - \frac{ x^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big) \ d \frac{ x^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \\ &= - \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } t } \exp \Big( - \frac{ x^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big) \mid_{t}^\infty \\ &= \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } t } \exp \Big( - \frac{ t^2 }{ 2 \sigma^2 } \Big). \end{aligned} Pr[X>t]​=∫t∞​2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ2x2​) dx≤∫t∞​2πσ2​1​tx​exp(−2σ2x2​) dx≤2π​tσ​∫t∞​exp(−2σ2x2​) d2σ2x2​=−2π​tσ​exp(−2σ2x2​)∣t∞​=2π​tσ​exp(−2σ2t2​).​

This bound is more useful only when we know that t≥σ2πt \ge \frac{ \sigma }{ \sqrt{2 \pi } }t≥2π​σ​.

Reference
